body.stage: Scene.--Athens; before the houses of LYSIMACHUS and DEMIPHO which are adjacent to each other.

div2.head: THE SUBJECT.
div2.p: THIS Play (which is thought by some not to have been the composition of Plautus) describes the follies of a vicious old man and his son. Two years before the period when the Play opens, Charinus has been sent by his father Demipho to traffic at Rhodes. Returning thence, he brings with him a young woman, named Pasicompsa, who is in reality his mistress, but whom he pretends to have purchased for the purpose of her being an attendant upon his mother. Demipho, in the absence of his son, goes down to the ship, and seeing the young woman there, falls desperately in love with her. He then pretends to Charinus that she is too handsome to be brought into the house as a servant, and that she must be sold again. Insisting upon this, he persuades his friend, Lysimachus, to purchase her for him in his own name, and to take her to his own house. This being done, and the damsel brought to the house, the wife of Lysimachus unexpectedly returns home from the country, and finds her there. In the meanwhile, Charinus, being reduced to despair on losing his mistress, determines to leave the country. His friend Eutychus, the son of Lysimachus, having discovered his friend's mistress in his father's house, stops him just as he is about to depart, and informs him where she has been found. He then reconciles his own parents, and the Play concludes with his very just censure of Demipho for his vicious conduct.

div2.head: THE ACROSTIC ARGUMENT. [Supposed to have been written by Priscian the Grammarian.]
div2.p: A YOUNG man, being sent (Missus) by his father to traffic, buys (Emit) a damsel of remarkable beauty, and brings her home. The old man, after he has seen her, makes enquiry (Requirit) who she is. The servant pretends (Confingit) that she has been bought by the son as an attendant for his mother. The old man falls in love with (Amat) her, and pretending that he has sold her, gives her in the charge of (Tradit) his neighbour. His wife thinks that he has brought (Obduxe) a mistress home. Then his friend stops (Retrahit) Charinus in his flight, after he has discovered his mistress.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Two things have I now resolved to do at the same time; both the subject and my own amours will I disclose. I am not doing like as I have seen other lovers do in Comedies, who relate their woes either to the night or to the day, or to the Sun or to the Moon; who, faith, I don't suppose pay much regard to the complaints of mortals, either what they wish or what they don't wish. To yourselves in preference will I now relate my woes. In the Greek this Play is called the EmporosEmporos: The Greek word e)mporo\s, signifying "a merchant." of Philemon; the same in the Latin is the Mercator of Marcus Accius. My father sent me hence to trade at Rhodes. Two years have now passed since I left home. There I began to love a fair one of remarkable beauty. But how I was captivated by her, I'll tell you, if you'll lend ear, and if you'll have the kindness to give your attention to this. And yet in this, but little have I followed the method of our forefathers in my own person, and on the spot as a tell- taleAs a tell-tale: He apologizes for his apparent boldness in breaking in upon them, and commencing to relate his amours, without first asking their leave. of my own amours am I represented before you. But all these failings are wont to attend on love--care, trouble, and refinement overmuch. Not only him who loves, but every one to whom this latter fault extends, him with a great and weighty evil does it affect; nor by my troth, in fact, does any one aim at refinement, beyond what his means allow of, without heavy disaster. But to love as well are these evils incident, which I have not as yet recounted--sleeplessness, a troubled mind, confusion, terror, and apprehension, trifling, and folly even, rashness too, thoughtlessness, foolhardy impudence, wantonness, lust, and malevolence; covetousness is inherent as well, idleness, injustice, want, contumely and wastefulness, talkativeness or moody silence. This latter is the fact, because things which relate not to the purpose, nor are of utility, the same does the lover give utterance to full oft at an unseasonable moment; and yet again, this moody silence for this reason do I commend, because no lover is ever so skilled in eloquence, as to be enabled to give utterance to that which is for his own interest. You, then, must not be offended with myself for my babbling; Venus bestowed it upon me on that same day on which this passion. To that point am I resolved to return, that what I commenced upon I may disclose. In the first place, when in life I had passed from my boyish days, and my disposition was weaned from childish pursuits, I began distractedly to love a Courtesan in this place. Forthwith, unknown to my father, my means went to be wasted upon her; an exacting Procurer, the owner of this damsel, by every method that he could, grasped everything into his own possessionGrasped everything into his own possession: Rapiebat domum. Literally "he carried off home.". Night and day my father censured me for this; represented the perfidy, the wickedness of Procurers; how that his own property was being forcibly rent in pieces, while that of this Procurer was increasing; this too in the loudest tones; sometimes muttering to himself; refusing to speak to me; even denying that I was his child; crying aloud through all the city and proclaiming that all should withhold from trusting me when desiring to borrow; that love had allured many a one to ruin; that I, passing all bounds, regardless of decency, and acting wrongfully, laid hands upon and tore whatever I could from him at home; that 'twas a most vile system that those choice possessions which he, by enduring every hardship, had acquired, should all be squandered away and parted with through the violence of my desire. That now for so many years he had supported myself, a reproach to him; that were I not ashamed, I ought not to desire to live. That he himself, at the very moment after he had passed his boyish days, did not, like me, devote his attention to love or indolence in slothfulness, nor, indeed, had he the control of himself, so very strictly by his father was he held in check; that in the various sordid pursuits of the country he was employed, and that only every fifth year even was he then enabled to visit the city, and that immediately after he had had a sight of the FestivalHad had a sight of the Festival: "Spectavisset peplum." Literally, "had seen the show of the garment." At the great Panathenæa, or Festival of Minerva, which was celebrated every fifth year, the "peplum" of Minerva was exposed to public view. A procession was afterwards formed, to carry it to the Temple of Minerva, or Athene Polias. The "peplum" was a garment of crocus colour, woven by virgins. On it were represented the conquest of Enceladus and the Giants by Minerva. The garment was not carried by hands, but on the mast of a ship; and this ship, which was usually kept near the Areiopagus, was moved along by machinery., back again instantly into the country was he wont to be driven by his father. That there by far the most of all the household did he toil, while thus his father would say to him: "For yourself you are ploughing, for yourself you harrow, for yourself you sow, for your own self too do you reap; for yourself, in fine, will this labour be productive of happiness." That after life had left his father's body, he had sold the farm, and with that money had bought for himself a bark of fifteen tonsOf fifteen tons: "Metretas trecentas." Literally, "three hundred metretæ." The "metreta" was properly a Greek liquid measure of about nine gallons. If, as some of the books inform us, in weight it was equal to one hundred-weight, three hundred of them would make fifteen tons. It is, however, not improbable that the word really signifies a weight nearer in capacity to a ton than to a hundred-weight., and with the same had transported merchandize to every quarter, even until he had acquired the property which he then possessed. That I ought to do the same, if I would be as it behoved me to be. I, when I found that I was disliked by my father and was an object of hate to him whom I was bound to please, distracted and in love as I was, resolutely made up my mind. I said that I would go to traffic, if he pleased; that I would renounce my amour, so as to be obedient to him. He gave me thanks, and praised my good feeling, but failed not to exact my promise; he built a merchant-shipA merchant-ship: "Cercurum." The merchant-ships, which were called "cercuri," are said to have been so called from the island of Corcyra, or Cercyra, so famous for its traffic, where they were said to have been first built. Some writers suppose them to have originally been peculiar to the inhabitants of the Isle of Cyprus., and purchased merchandize; the ship ready, he placed it on board; besides, to myself with his own hand he paid down a talent of silver; with me he sent a servant, who formerly had been my tutor from the time when I was a little child, to be as though a guardian to me. These things completed, we set sail; we came to Rhodes, where the merchandize which I had brought I sold to my mind according as I wished; I made great profits, beyond the estimate of the merchandize which my father had given me; and so I made a large sum. But while in the harbour I was walking there, a certain stranger recognized me, and invited me to dinner. I went, and took my place at table, being merrily and handsomely entertained. When at night we went to rest, behold, a female came to me, than whom not another female is there more charming. That night, by order of my entertainer, did she pass with me; consider your own selves, how very much he gratified me. Next day, I went to my host; I begged him to sell her to me; I said that for his kindnesses I should ever be grateful and obliged. What need is there of talking? I bought her, and yesterday I brought her hither. I don't wish my father to come to know I've brought her. For the present, I've left her and a servant in the harbour on board the ship. But why do I see my servant running hither from the harbour, whom I forbade to leave the ship? I dread what the reason may be. Stands aside.

div2.stage: Enter ACANTHIO, at a distance, in haste.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: to himself. With your utmost power and might always try and endeavour that your younger masterYour younger master: "Herus minor." One version renders these words, "your master when thrown down." That surely cannot be the meaning of the passage. may by your aid be preserved. Come then, Acanthio, away with weariness from you; take care and be on your guard against sloth. At the same time put an end to this panting; troth, I can hardly fetch my breath; at the same time, too, drive right full against all those persons who come in the way, shove them aside, and push them into the road. This custom here is a very bad one; no one thinks it proper for him to give way to one who is running and in haste; and thus three things must be done at the same moment, when you have commenced upon but one; you must both run and fight, and squabble as well, upon the road.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: apart. What's the reason of this, that he's requiring speed for himself at a rate so rapid? I have some anxiety, what the business is, or what news he brings.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: to himself. I'm trifling about it. The more I stop, the greater the risk that's run.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: apart. He brings news of some misfortune, I know not what.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: to himself. His knees are failing this runner. I'm undone, my spleen is in rebellionSpleen is in rebellion: He alludes to the expansion of the spleen by the act of running fast., it's taking possession of my breast. I'm done up, I can't draw my breath. A very worthless piper should I be. I' faith, not all the baths will ever remove this lassitude from me. Am I to say that my master Charinus is at home or abroad?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: apart. I'm doubtful in my mind what the matter is; I'd like for myself to learn of him, that I may become acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: to himself. But why still standing here? Why still hesitating to make splinters of this door? Knocks at the door of DEMIPHO'S house, and calls. Open the door, some one. Where's my master, Charinus? Is he at home or abroad? Does any one think fit to come to the door?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: presenting himself. Why, here am I, whom you're looking for, Acanthio.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: not seeing him. There is nowhere a more lazy management than in his house.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What matter is afflicting you so terribly?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: turning round. Many, master, both yourself and me.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: We are undone.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: That beginning do you present unto our foes.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: But your own self it has befallen, as fate would have it.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Tell me this matter, whatever it is.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Quietly--I want to take a rest. He pants.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: But, i' faith, do take the skirt of your coatSkirt of your coat: "Laciniam." The "laciniæ" were the angular extremities of the "pallium," and the "toga," one of which was brought round over the left shoulder. It was generally tucked into the girdle, but was sometimes allowed to hang loose. From the present passage, we may conclude that it was sometimes devoted to the purposes of a pocket-handkerchief., and wipe the sweat from off you.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: For your sake, I've burst the veins of my lungs; I'm spitting blood already. He spits.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Swallow Ægyptian resin with honey; you'll make it all right.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Then, i' faith, do you drink hot pitchDrink hot pitch: Commentators have been at a loss to know why Acanthio should be so annoyed at the recommendation of Charinus, and why he should answer him in these terms. The ingenious Rost seems in a great measure to have hit upon the true meaning of the passage. Charinus tells him that a mixture of resin and honey is good for the lungs. Now, from what Pliny says, B. 24, ch. 6, we should have reason to suppose that some kinds of resin were used in diseases of the lungs. But, on the other hand, Aristotle, in his History of Animals, B. 8, ch. 24, mentions a certain resin called "sandonache," which was of a poisonous nature. Acanthio, then, may have been frightened from a previous knowledge of the doubtful nature of resins as a remedy; he may also have heard that the Egyptians preserved their mummies with honey and resin, and his stomach may have revolted at swallowing such a mixture; and, thinking that his master is trifling with him, he answers him in anger. The latter explanation will appear the more probable when we remember, that as honey and resin were used for the embalming of the higher classes, the bodies of the poorer persons in Egypt were preserved by being dipped in pitch; and though this did not suggest itself to Rost, it is not improbable that the servant intends by his answer to repay his master in the same coin. Perhaps he may have imagined that his master intended him to swallow the mixture in a hot, melted state, just as when it was injected into the mummies. Persons convicted of blasphemy were sometimes condemned to swallow melted pitch; then your troubles will vanish.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I know no one a more tetchy fellow than yourself.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: And I know no one more abusive than yourself

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: But what if I'm persuading you to that which I take to be for your benefit?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Away with benefit of that sort, that's accompanied with pain.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Tell me, is there any good at all that any one can enjoy entirely without evil; or where you mustn't endure labour when you wish to enjoy it?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: I don't understand these things; I never learnt to philosophize, and don't know how. I don't want any good to be given me, to which evil is an accompaniment.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: extending his hand. Come now, Acanthio, give me your right hand.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: It shall be given; there then, take it. Gives his hand.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Do you intend yourself to be obedient to me, or don't you intend it?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: You may judge by experience, as I've ruptured myself with running for your sake, in order that what I knew, you might have the means of knowing directly.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I'll make you a free man within a few months.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: You are smoothing me down.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What, should I presume ever to make mention of an untrue thing to you? On the contrary, before I said so, you knew already whether I intend to utter an untruth.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Ah! your words, upon my faith, are increasing my weakness. You are worrying me to death!

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What, is this the way you're obedient to me?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: What do you want me to do?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What, you? What I want is this----

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: What is it then that you do want?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I'll tell you.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Tell me, then.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: But still, I'd like to do it in a quiet way.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Are you afraid lest you should wake the drowsy SpectatorsThe drowsy Spectators: No wonder if this most tiresome dialogue has sent them to sleep. from their nap?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Woe be to you!

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: For my part, that same am I bringing to you from the harbour.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What are you bringing? Tell me.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Violence, alarm, torture, care, strife, and beggary.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I'm undone! You really are bringing me hither a store of evils. I'm ruined outright.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Why, yes, you are----

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I know it already; you'll be saying I'm wretched.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: 'Tis you have said so; I'm mum.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What mishap is this?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Don't enquire. It is a very great calamity.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Prithee, do relieve me at once. Too long a time have I been in suspense.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Softly; I still wish to make many enquiries before I'm beaten.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: By my troth, you assuredly will be beaten, unless you say at once, or get away from here.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Do look at that, please, how he does coax me; there's no one more flattering when he sets about it.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: By heavens, I do entreat and beseech you to disclose to me at once what it is; inasmuch as I see that I must be the suppliant of my own servant.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: And do I seem so unworthy of it?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Oh no, quite worthy.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Well, so I thought.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Prithee, is the ship lost?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: The ship's all right; don't fear about that.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Well then, the rest of the cargo?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: That's right and tight.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Why then don't you tell me what it is, for which, just now, running through the city, you were seeking me?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Really, you are taking the words out of my mouth.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I'll hold my tongue.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Do hold your tongue. I doubt, if I brought you any good news, you'd be dreadfully pressing, who are now insisting upon my speaking out, when you must hear bad news.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Troth then, prithee do you let me know what this misfortune is.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Since you beg of me, I'll tell you. Your father----

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: My father did what?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Your mistress----

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What about her?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: He has seen her.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Seen her? Ah wretch that I am! What I ask you, answer me.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Nay, but do you ask me, if you want anything.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: How could he see her?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: With his eyes.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Wide open.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Away hence and be hanged. You are trifling, when my life's at stake.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: How the plague am I trifling, if I answer you what you ask me?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Did he see her for certain?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Aye, troth, as certainly as I see you and you see me.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Where did he see her?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Down on board the ship, as he stood near the prow and chatted with her.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Father, you have undone me. Come now, you, come now, you sir? Why, you whip-rascal, didn't you take care that he mightn't see her? Why, villain, didn't you stow her away, that my father mightn't perceive her?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Because we were busily employed about our business; we were engaged in packing up and arranging the cargo. While these things were being done, your father was brought alongside in a very small boat; and not an individual beheld the man until he was aboard the ship.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: In vain have I escaped the sea with its dreadful tempests! Just now I really did suppose that I was both ashore and in a place of safety; but I see that by the raging waves I am being hurried towards the rocks. Say on; what took place?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: After he espied the woman, he began to ask her to whom she belonged.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What did she answer?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: That instant I ran up and interposed, saying that you had bought her as a maid-servant for your mother.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Did he seem to believe you in that?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Do you e'en ask me that? Why the rogue began to take liberties with her.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Prithee, what, with her?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: 'Twere a wonder if he had taken liberties with myself.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: By heavens, my heart is saddened, which, drop by drop is melting away, just as though you were to put salt in water. I'm undone.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Aye, aye, that one expression have you most truly uttered.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: This is mere folly. What shall I do? I do think. my father won't believe me if I say that I bought her for my mother; and then, besides, it seems to me a shame that I should tell a lie to my parent. He'll neither believe, nor indeed is it credible, that I bought this woman of surpassing beauty as a maid-servant for my mother.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Won't you be quiet, you most silly man? Troth, he will believe it, for he just now believed me.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I'm dreadfully afraid that a suspicion will reach my father how the matter really stands. Prithee, answer me this that I ask you.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: What do you ask?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Did he seem to suspect that she was my mistress?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: He did not seem. On the contrary, in everything, just as I said it, he believed me.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: As being true-as he seemed to yourself at least.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Not so; but he really did believe me.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Ah! wretched man that I am! I'm ruined! But why do I kill myself here with repining, and don't be off to the ship? Follow me. Hastening along.

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: If you go that way, you'll conveniently come slap upon your father. As soon as he shall see you, dismayed and out of spirits, at once he'll be stopping you, and enquiring where you bought her, and for how much you bought her; he'll be trying you in your dismay.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: turning about. I'll go this way in preference. Do you think that by this my father has left the harbour?

sp.speaker: ACANTHIO
sp.p: Why, it was for that reason I ran before him hither, that he mightn't come upon you unawares and fish it out of you.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Very properly done. (Exeunt.)

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: to himself. In wondrous waysIn wondrous ways: -5. These lines occur also in the Rudens, l. 593. do the Gods make sport of men, and in wondrous fashions do they send dreams in sleep. As, for instance, I, this very last night that has passed, have sufficiently experienced in my sleep, and, mortal that I am, was much occupied therewith. I seemed to have purchased for myself a beautiful she-goat. That she might not offend that other she-goat which I had at home before, and that they mightn't disagree if they were both in the same spot, after that I had purchased her, I seemed to entrust her to the charge of an ape. This ape, not very long afterwards, came to me, uttered imprecations against me, and assailed me with reproaches; he said that by her means and through the arrival of the she-goat he had suffered injury and loss in no slight degree; he said that the she-goat, which I had entrusted to him to keep, had gnawed away the marriage-portion of his wife. This seemed extremely wonderful to me, how that this single she-goat could possibly have gnawed awayCould possibly have gnawed away: There is a poor play on words. here with reference to "una;" how "one" goat could "ambadederit," "gnaw away," or "doubly eat" (literally speaking) the dowry--that is, how one goat could do the work of two. the marriage-portion of the wife of the ape. The ape, however, insisted that it was so, and, in short, gave me this answer, that if I didn't make baste and remove her away from his own house, he would bring her home into my house to my wife. And, by my troth, I seemed very greatly to take an interest in her, but not to have any one to whom to entrust this she-goat; wherefore the more, in my distress, was I tormented with anxiety what to do. Meanwhile, a kid appeared to address me, and began to tell me that he had carried off the she-goat from the ape, and began to laugh at me. But I began to lament and complain that she was carried off. To what reality I am to suppose that this vision points, I can't discover; except that I suspect that I have just now discovered this she-goat, what she is, or what it all means. This morning, at daybreak, I went away hence down to the harbour. After I had transacted there what I wanted, suddenly I espied the ship from Rhodes, in which my son arrived here yesterday. I had an inclination, I know not why, to visit it; I went on board a boat, and put off to the ship; and there I beheld a woman of surpassing beauty, whom my son has brought as a maid-servant for his mother. After I had thus beheld her, I fell in love with her, not as men in their senses, but after the fashion in which madmen are wont. I' faith, in former times, in my youthful days, I fell in love, 'tis true; but after this fashion, according as I'm now distracted, never. Now beyond a doubt, surely thus this matter stands; this is that she-goat. But what that ape and that kid mean, I'm afraid. One thing, i' faith, I really do know for certain, that I'm undone for love; to the AUDIENCE consider yourselves the other point, what a poor creature I amWhat a poor creature I am: This seems to be the real meaning of "quanti siem;" Gueudeville has adopted it; but there is considerable difference of opinion among the Commentators on the sense of the passage.. But I'll hold my tongue; lo! I see my neighbour; he's coming out of doors. Stands aside.

div2.stage: Enter LYSIMACHUS and a SERVANT with some rakes, from the house of the former.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Really I will have this goat mutilated, that's giving us so much trouble at the farm.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: apart. Neither this omen nor this augury pleases me; I'm afraid that my wife will be just now mutilating me like the he-goat, and be acting the part of this same ape.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Do you go hence to my country-house, and take care and deliver personally into his own hands those rakes to the bailiff Pistus himself. Take care and tell my wife that I have business in the city, so that she mayn't expect me; for do you mention that I have three causes coming on for judgment to-day. Be off, and remember to say this.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Anything more?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: That's enough. (Exit)

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Stepping forward. Greetings to you, Lysimachus.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Well met! and greetings to you, Demipho. How are you? How goes it?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: As with one that's most wretchedAs with one that's most wretched: "Quod miserrimus" Literally 'what a very wretched person does.".

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: May the Gods grant better things.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: As for the Gods, it's they that do this.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I'd tell you, if I saw that you had time or leisure.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Although I have business in hand, if you wish for anything, Demipho, I'm never too busy to give attention to a friend.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: You speak of your kindness to myself who have experienced it. How do I seem to you as to age?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: A subject for Acheron--an antiquated, decrepit old fellow.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: You see in a wrong light. I am a child, Lysimachus, of seven years old.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Are you in your senses, to say that you are a child?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I'm telling what's true.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: I' faith, it has this moment come into my mind what you mean to say; directly a person is old, no longer has he sense or taste; people say that he has become a child again.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Why, no; for I'm twice as hearty as ever I was before.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: I' faith, it's well that so it is, and I'm glad of it.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Aye, and if you did but know; with my eyes, too, I see even better now than I did formerly.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: That's good.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Of a thing that's bad, I'm speaking.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Then that same is not good.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: But, if I wished at all, could I venture to disclose something to you?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Boldly.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Give heed, then.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: It shall be carefully done.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: This day, Lysimachus, I've begun to go to school to learn my letters. I know three letters already.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: How? Three letters?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: spelling. A M O [I am in love].

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: What! you, in love, with your hoary head, you most shocking old fellow?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Whether that is hoary, or whether red, or whether black, I'm in love.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: You're now playing upon me in this, I fancy, Demipho.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Cut my throat, if it's false, what I'm saying. That you may be sure I'm in love, take a knife, and do you cut off either my finger, or my ear, or my nose, or my lip: if I move me, or feel that I'm being cut, then, Lysimachus, I give you leave to torture me to death here with being in love.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: aside to the AUDIENCE. If ever you've seen a lover in a picture, why, there he is pointing at DEMIPHO: for really, in my way of thinking, an antiquated, decrepit old man is just about the same as though he were a figure painted upon a wall.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Now, I suppose, you are thinking of censuring me.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: What, I, censure you?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Well, there's no reason that you should censure me. Other distinguished men have done the like before. It's natural to be in love, it's natural, as well, to be considerate. Then, please, don't reprove me; no inclination impelled me to this.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Why, I'm not reproving you.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: But still, don't you think any the worse of me for acting thus.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: I, think the worse of you? O, may the Deities forbid it.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Still, please, only do take care of that.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Due care is taken.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Quite sure?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: You're wearing me out. Aside. This person's deranged through love. To DEMIPHO. Do you desire aught with me?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Farewell!

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: I'm making haste to the harbour; for I've got business there.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Good luck go with you.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Heartily fare you well.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Kindly fare you well. (Exit LYSIMACHUS.) DEMIPHO continues, to himself. And what's more, I too as well have got some business at the harbour; now, therefore, I shall be off thither. But, look! most opportunely I see my son. I'll wait for the fellow; it's necessary for me now to see him, to persuade him, as far as I possibly can, to sell her to me, and not make a present of her to his mother; for I've heard that he has brought her as a present for her. But I have need of precaution, that he mayn't any way imagine that I have set my fancy upon her.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: to himself. Never, I do think, was any person more wretched than myself, nor one who had more everlasting crosses. Isn't it the fact, that whatever thing there is that I have commenced to attempt, it cannot fall out to my wish according as I desire? To such an extent is some evil fortune always befalling me, which overwhelms my fair intentions. To my misfortune, I procured me a mistress to please my inclination; I acquired her for a sum of money, fancying that I could keep her unknown to my father. He has found her out, and has seen her, and has undone me. Nor have I yet determined what to say when he asks me, so much do uncertain thoughts, aye, tenfold, struggle within my breast; nor know I now in my mind what resolution I can possibly take; so much uncertainty, mingled with anxiety, is there in my feelings, at one moment the advice of my servant pleases me, then again it doesn't please me, and it doesn't seem possible for my father to be induced to think that she was bought as a maid-servant for my mother. Now, if I say, as is the fact, and declare that I purchased her for myself, what will he think of me? He may take her away, too, and carry her hence beyond sea, to be sold! Well taught at home, I know how severe he is. Is this, then, being in love? I'd rather be at the plough-tailRather be at the plough-tail: "Arare mavelim, quam sic amare." There is an insipid play upon the resemblance of the words "arare," "to plough," and "amare" "to love." than love in this fashion. Before to-day, long ago, he drove me away against my inclination from his house, my home, and bade me go and traffic. There did I meet with this misfortune. When its misery can surpass its pleasure, what is there delightful in it? In vain I've hidden her, concealed her, kept her in secret; my father's a very flyA very fly: The flies of those days seem to have been as annoying and inquisitive as those of modern times. "Muscæ" was a term of reproach for Parasites and busybodies.; nothing can be kept away from him; nothing so sacred or so profane is there, but that he's there at once; neither have I any assured hope in my mind through which to feel confidence in my fortunes.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: apart. What's the reason of this, that my son is talking to himself alone? He seems to me anxious about some matter, I know not what.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: looking round. Heyday, now! Why, surely it's my father here that I see. I'll go and accost him. Accosting him. How goes it, father?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Whence do you come? Why are you in a hurry, my son?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: It's all right, father.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: So I trust; but what's the reason that your colour's so changed? Do you feel ill at all?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I know not what it is affects my spirits, father; this last night I didn't rest quite as well as I wished.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: As you've been travelling by sea, your eyes, I suppose, are at present rather unaccustomed to the shore.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: No doubt it is that; but it will be going off presently.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Troth, it's for that reason you are pale; if you were prudent, you'd go home and lie down.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I haven't the leisure; I wish to attend to business on commission.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Attend to it to-morrow; the day after, attend to it.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I've often heard from you, father, it behoves all wise men, the first thing, to give their earliest attention to business upon commission.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Do so, then; I have no wish to be striving against your opinion.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: aside. I'm all right, if, indeed, his adherence to that sentiment is immoveable and lasting.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: aside. Why is it that he calls himself aside into counsel with himself? I'm not afraid now lest he should be able to come to know that I'm in love with her, because I've not as yet done anything in a foolish manner, as people in love are wont to do.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: aside. I' faith, the affair for the present is really quite safe; for I'm quite certain that he doesn't know anything about that mistress of mine; if he did know, his talk would have been different.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: aside. Why don't I accost him about her?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: aside. Why don't I betake myself off hence? Aloud. I'm going to deliver the commissions from my friends to their friends. Moves as if going.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Nay, but stop; I still want to make a few enquiries of you first.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Say what it is you wish.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Have you all along been well?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Quite well all the time, so long, indeed, as I was there; but as soon as I had arrived here in harbour, I don't know what faintness it was came over me.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I' faith, I suppose it arose from sea-sickness; but it will be going off just now. But how say you? What servant-maid is this that you have brought from Rhodes for your mother?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I've brought one.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Well, what sort of a woman is she as to appearance?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Not an ill-favored one, i' faith.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: How is she as to manners?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: In my way of thinking, I never saw one better.

sp.speaker: DEN.
sp.p: So, indeed, i' faith, she seemed to me when I saw her.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: How now, have you seen her, father?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I have seen her; but she doesn't suit our ways, and so she doesn't please me.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Because she hasn't a figure suitable to our establishment; we stand in need of no female servant but one who can weave, grind, chop wood, make yarn, sweep out the house, stand a beating, and who can have every day's victuals cooked for the household. This one will be able to do not any single one of these things.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Why, in fact, for this reason I purchased her, to make a present of her to my mother.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Don't you be giving her, nor mention that you have brought her.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: aside. The Deities favour me.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: aside. I'm shaking him by slow degrees. Aloud. But, what I omitted to say,--she can neither with due propriety follow your mother as an attendant; nor will I allow it.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: But why?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Because, with those good looks, it would be scandalous if she were to be following a matron when she's walking through the streets; all people would be staring, gazing, nodding, winking, hissing, twitching, crying out, be annoying, and singing serenades at our door; my door, perhaps, would be filled with the charcoal marksWith the charcoal marks: Colman, who translated this Play in Thornton's edition, has this Note here: "Some consider these words as alluding to defamatory, rather than commendatory verses, alleging that praise was written in chalk, and scandal in coal. 'Ilia prius chartâ, mox hæc carbone.' I have followed the opinion, however, of other Commentators, who suppose that in these cases chalk, or coal, or lighted torches, were used indiscriminately, according to the colour of the ground--as a Poet would write a panegyric in black ink upon white paper, or a lover delineate the name of his mistress with the smoke of a candle on a white-washed ceiling." of her praises; and, according as persons are scandalizing at the present day, they might throw it in the teeth of my wife and myself, that we are carrying on the business of a Procurer. Now what occasion is there for this?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Why, faith, you say what's just, and I agree with you. But what shall be done with her now?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Exactly; I'll buy for your mother some stout wench of a female slave, not a bad servant, but of ungainly figure, as befits the mistress of a family--either a Syrian or an Egyptian woman: she shall do the grinding, spin out the yarn, and stand a lashing; and on her account no disgrace at all will be befalling our doors.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What then if she is restored to the person of whom she was purchased?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: By no means in the world.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: He said that he would take her back, if she didn't suit.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: There's no need of that; I don't want you to get into litigation, nor yet your honor to be called in question. I' troth, I would much rather, if any must be endured, put up with the loss myself, than that disgrace or scandal on account of a woman should be brought upon my house. I think that I am able to sell for you at a good profit.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I' faith, so long, indeed, as you don't be selling her at a less price than I bought her at, father.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Do you only hold your tongue; there is a certain old gentleman who commissioned me to buy one for him of just that same appearance.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: But, father, a certain young man commissioned me to buy one for him of just that same appearance that she is of.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I think that I am able to dispose of her for twenty minæ.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: But, if I had chosen, there have been already seven-and-twenty minæ offered.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: But I----

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Nay, but I, I say----

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: But you don't know what I was going to say; do hold your tongue. I can add three minæ even to that, so that there will be thirty. Looks as though on one side at a distance.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What are you turning yourself towards?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Towards him who's making the purchase.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: staring about. Why, where in the world is this person?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Look there, I see himThere, I see him: He says this by way of joking, just for the moment, in order to withdraw his son's notice from the manifest iniquity of which he is guilty., yonder pointing; he's bidding me even still to add five minæ.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: aside. By my troth, may the Gods send a curse upon him, whoever he is!

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: looking in the distance. There he is again, making a sign to me, even still, for me to add six minæ.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: My man is bidding seven minæ, for her, full weight, father. Aside. I' faith, he shall never this day outdo me.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: He's bidding in vain; I will have her!

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: But the other one made the first offer.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I care nothing for that.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: He bids fifty.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: No, a hundred's the offer. Can't you desist from bidding against the determination of my mind. I' troth, you'll be having an immense profit, in such a way is this old gentleman for whom she's being purchased. He's not in his senses by reason of his love; whatever you ask, you'll get.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I' faith, that young man, for whom I'm purchasing, is assuredly dying with distraction for love of her.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Troth, very much more so is that old gentleman, if you did but know it.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I' faith, that old man never was nor ever will be more distracted with love than that young man, father, to whom I'm lending this assistance.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Do be quiet, I tell you; I'll see to that matter, that it's all right.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: How say you----?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I didn't take her for a slave; but it was he that took her for such.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Let me alone.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: By law you cannot put her up for sale.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I'll somehow see to that.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: And then besides, she's the common property of myself and another person; how do I know how he's disposed, whether he does wish or doesn't wish to sell her?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I'm sure he does wish.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: But, i' faith, I believe that there's a certain person who doesn't wish.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What matters that to me?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Because it's right that he should have the disposal of his own property.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What is it you say?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: She is the common property of myself and another person; he isn't here at present.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: You are answering me before I ask.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You are buying, father, before I sell. I don't know, I say, whether he chooses to part with her or not.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: But if she is purchased for that certain person who gave you the commission, will he choose it then? If I purchase her for that person who gave me the commission, will he then not choose it? You avail nothing. Never, on my faith, shall any person have her in preference to the person that I wish. That I'm resolved upon.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Have you made up your mind that it is resolved upon?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Why, I'm going hence at once to the ship; there she shall be sold.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Do you wish me to go there with you?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I don't wish you.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You don't choose it, then.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: It's better for you to give your earliest attention to the business which you've been commissioned upon.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You are hindering me from doing so.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Then do you make your excuse that you have used all diligence. Don't you go to the harbour, I tell you that now.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: That shall be attended to.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: aside. I'll be off to the harbour, and (I have need of caution lest he should find it out) I'll not buy her myself, but commission my friend Lysimachus; he said just now that he was going to the harbour. I'm delaying while I'm standing here. (Exit.)

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p:
wringing his hands, and crying aloud. I'm lost--I'm undone. They say that the Bacchanals tore Pentheus to piecesTore Pentheus to pieces: Pentheus, king of Thebes, was torn in pieces by his mother Agave, and the other Bacchanalian women, for obstructing their celebration of the orgies of Bacchus. See the Metamorphoses of Ovid, B. 3, l. 720.. I do believe that that was the merest trifle compared with the manner in which I am rent asunder in different ways. Why do I exist? Why don't I die? What good is there for me in life? I'm determined, I'll go to a doctorTo a doctor: Colman renders "medicum," "an apothecary;" and remarks, that the passage may put the reader in mind of Shakspeare's Romeo in allusion to the passage commencing, "I do know an apothecary," &c., and there I'll put myself to death by poison, since that is being taken from me for the sake of which I desire to remain in existence. He is going off.
Enter EUTYCHUS, from the house of LYSIMACHUS.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Stop, prithee, stop, Charinus.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: turning. Who is it, that calls me back?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Eutychus, your friend and companion, your nearest neighbour as well.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You don't knowYou don't know: The note of interrogation in Weise's edition at the end of these words seems out of place. what a vast weight of my woes I am enduring.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: I do know. I listened to it all at the door: I know the whole matter.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What is it that you know?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Your father wishes to sell----

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You have the whole matter.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: --Your mistress----

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You know by far too much.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: --Against your wish.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You know everything. But how do you know that this woman is my mistress?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: You yourself told me yesterday.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Isn't it the fact that I had quite forgotten that I told you yesterday?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: It's not surprising it is so.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I now consult you. Answer me; by what death do you think that I should die in preference?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Won't you hold your peace? Take you care how you say that.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What then do you wish me to say?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Should you like me to trick your father nicely?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I really should like it.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Should you like me to walk to the harbour----

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What, rather than that you should fly?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: And release the fair one for a sum.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What, rather than you should pay her weight in gold?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Whence is it to come?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I'll entreat Achilles to lend me the gold with which Hector was ransomed

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Are you in your senses?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I' faith, if I were in my senses, I shouldn't be seeking you for my physician.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Do you wish her to be purchased for as high a price as he asks?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Throw in something by way of surplus; even a thousand didrachms more than he shall demand.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Now, do hold your peace. But what say you as to this? Whence will the money come, for you to give, when your father asks for it?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: It shall be found, it shall be sought out, something shall be done.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: You are worrying me to death. For I'm afraid of that "Something shall be done."

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Why won't you hold your tongue?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: You give your commands to one who is dumb.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Is this matter sufficiently pointed out to you?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Can't you possibly be attending to something else?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: It isn't possible.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: going. Kindly fare you well.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I' faith, I cannot fare well, before you come back to me.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: To better purpose, recover your senses.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Farewell, and prevail, and be my preserver.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: I'll do so. Wait for me at home.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Do you take care, then, to betake yourself back just now with the booty. (Exit EUTYCHUS, and CHARINUS goes into DEMIPHO'S house.)

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: to himself. I've lent my assistance to my friend in a friendly manner; this piece of goods, which my neighbour requested me, I've purchased. Turning to PASICOMPSA. You are my own; then follow me. Don't weep. You are acting very foolishly; spoiling such eyes. Why, really you have more reason to laugh than to be crying.

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: In the name of heaven, prithee, my good old gentleman, do tell me----

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Ask me what you please.

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: Why have you bought me?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: What, I, bought you? For you to do what you are bidden; in like manner what you bid me, I'll do.

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: I am determined, to the best of my ability and skill, to do what I shall think you desire.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: I shall bid you do nothing of laborious work.

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: Why, really, for my part, my good old gentleman, I haven't learnt, i' faith, to carry burdens, or to feed cattle at the farm, or to nurse children.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: If you choose to be a good girl, it shall be well for you.

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: Then, i' faith, to my sorrow, I'm undone.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: Because in the place from which I have been conveyed hither, it used to be well with the worthlessWell with the worthless: She seems to mean that at Rhodes, where she has lately come from, women of light character are treated better than those who are virtuous..

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: aside. By my troth, her talk alone is worth more than the sum that she was purchased at. To PASICOMPSA. As though you would say that no woman is good.

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: Indeed I don't say so; nor is it my way, to say a thing which I believe all people are acquainted with.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: I want to ask this one thing of you.

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: I'll answer you when you ask.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: What say you now? What am I to say your name is?

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: Pasicompsa.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: The name was given you from your good looksFrom your good looks: Coming from two Greek words, signifying "all graces," or "attractions.". But what say you, Pasicompsa? Can you, if occasion should arise, spin a fine woof?

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: I can.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: If you know how to do a fine one, I'm sure you can spin a coarser one.

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: For spinning, I fear no woman that's of the same age.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Upon my faith, I take it that you are good and industrious, since, young woman, now that you are grown up, you know how to do your duty.

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: I' faith, I learned it from a skilful mistress. I won't let my work be called in question.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Well, thus the matter stands, i' faith. Look now, I'll give you a sheep for your own, one sixty years old.

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: My good old gentleman, one so old as that?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: It's of the Grecian breed. If you take care of it, it is a very good one; it is shorn very easily.

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: For the sake of the compliment, whatever it is that shall be given me, I shall receive it with thanks.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Now, damsel, that you mayn't be mistaken, you are not mine; so don't think it.

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: Prithee, tell me, then, whose I am?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: You've been bought back for your own master. I've bought you back for himBack for him: She imagines all along that by the word "master" he means the young man Charinus; whereas Demipho is really intended.; he requested me to do so.

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: My spirits have returned, if good faith is kept with me.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Be of good courage; this person will give you your liberty. I' troth, he did so dote upon you this day as soon as ever he had seen you.

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: I' faith, it's now two years since he commenced his connexion with me. Now, as I'm sure that you are a friend of his, I'll disclose it.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: How say you? Is it now two years since he formed the connexion with you?

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: Certainly, it is; and we agreed, on oath, between ourselves, I with him, and he with me, that I would never have intercourse with any man except himself, nor he with any woman except myself.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Immortal Gods! Isn't he even to sleep with his wife?

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: Prithee, is he a married man? He neither is nor will he be.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Indeed, I wish he wasn't. I' faith, the fellow has been committing perjury.

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: No young man do I more ardently love.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Why, really he's a child, you simpleton; for, in fact, it's not so very long a time since his teeth fell out.

sp.speaker: PASICOMPSA
sp.p: What? His teeth?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: It's no matter? Follow me this way, please; he requested that I would find you room for one day in my house, since my wife is away in the country. He goes into his house, followed by PASICOMPSA.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: to himself. At last I've managed to ruin myself; a mistress has been purchased for me without the knowledge of my wife and son. I'm resolved on it; I'll have recourse again to former habits and enjoy myself. In my allotment of existence, almost now run through, the little that there remains of life, I'll cheer up with pleasure, wine, and love. For it's quite proper for this time of life to enjoy itself. When you are young, then, when the blood is fresh, it's right to devote your exertions to acquiring your fortune; and then when at last, you are an old man, you may set yourself at your ease; drink, and be amorous; this, the fact that you are living, is now so much profit. This, as I say, I'll carry out in deed. Turning to his house. Meanwhile, however, I'll take a look in-doors here at my house; my wife has been some time expecting me at home quite hungry: now, she'll be worrying me to death with her scolding, if I go in-doors. But, in fine, whatever comes of it, i' faith, I'll not go, but I'll first meet this neighbour of mine before I return home; I want him to hire some house for me, where this damsel may dwell. And, see, he's coming out of doors.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: to PASICOMPSA, within. I'll bring him to you directly, if I meet him.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: behind. He's meaning me.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: turning about. How say you, Demipho?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Is the damsel at your house?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: What do you suppose?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What if I go see her? Moves towards the house.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Why making such haste? Stay.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What am I to do?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: What you ought to do; take care and consider.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Consider what? Why troth, for my own part, I think there's need for my doing this, going in-doors there, I mean.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: What, is it so, you old wether? Would you be going in?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What should I do else?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: First listen to this, and attend; there's something even before this that I think it proper you should do. For if you now go in-doors to her, you'll be wishing to embrace her, chatting with her, and kissing her.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Really you know my feelings; you understand what I would be at.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: You will be doing wrong.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: What, with that which you love?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: So much the less reason. Would you, full of hungriness, with a foul breath, a stinking old fellow, be kissing a woman? And wouldn't you, as you approached, be setting a female vomiting?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I' faith, I'm sure that you're in love, as you point out these things beforehand to me. What then, if I give a dinner? If you approve of this, let's lay hold of some cook, who may be cooking away a mealCooking away a meal: "Prandium" here does not mean the morning meal, similar to our breakfast, but a "feast" or "banquet in general. here at your house, even until the evening.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Well, I'm of that way of thinking. Now you are talking wisely, and like a lover.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Why are we standing here? Why then don't we be off and procure the provisions, that we may be comfortable?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: For my part, I'll follow you. And, i' troth, you'll be finding out a lodging for her, if you are prudent; for, i' faith, she shan't be at my house a single day beyond the present; I'm afraid of my wife, lest, if she should return from the country to-morrow, she'll be finding her here. (Exeunt.)

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p:
to himself. Am I not a wretched mortal, who can rest quietly nowhere? If I'm at home, my mind's abroad; but if I'm abroad, my mind's at home. To such a degree. has love kindled a flame in my breast and in my heart; did not the tears fall from my eyes, why then, I doubt, my head would be on fire. I cling to hope; safety I've lost; whether she'll return or no, I know not. If my father seizes her, as he has said, then my welfare is gone in exile; but if my companion has done what he promised, then my welfare has not departed. But still, even if Eutychus had had gouty feet, he could have been back from the harbour by this. This is a very great fault of his, that he is too slow, against the wishes of my feelings. But looking towards the side isn't this he whom I espy running? 'Tis he himself; I'll go meet him. Clasps his hands. Thou who art the overlooker of Gods and of men and the mistress of mortals as well, inasmuch as thou hast indulged me in this hope that I entertained, I do return thee thanks. Does any hope remain? Alas! I'm utterly undone. His countenance by no means pleases me! He moves along in sadness. My breast burns. I am in doubt. He shakes his head. Eutychus!
Enter EUTYCHUS.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Alas! Charinus. He pants.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Before you take breath, in one word, speak out. Where am I? Here, or among the dead?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: You are neither among the dead nor here.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I'm saved, immortality has been vouchsafed me--he has purchased her. He has nicely tricked my father. There's no one living more clever at gaining his purpose. Prithee, do tell me; if I'm neither here nor at Acheron, where am I?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Nowhere in the world.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I'm utterly undone! That speech has just put an end to me here. Whatever it is, do come to the material points of the matter.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: First of all, we are ruined.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: But why don't you in preference tell me that which I don't know? It is an annoying way of speaking, when you should despatch the business, to be beating about the bushTo be beating about the bush: Longinquum loqui; literally to be talking at a distance.".

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: The damsel has been taken away from you.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Eutychus, you are guilty of a capital offence.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Because you are killing your year's-mate and friend, a free citizen.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: May the Gods forbid it!

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You've thrust a sword into my throat; this moment I shall fall.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Troth now, prithee, don't be desponding in mind.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I have none to be desponding in. Tell on, then, the rest of your bad news; for whom has she been purchased?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: I don't know. She had been already knocked down to the bidder and taken off by him, when I got to the harbour.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Ah me! Already, indeed, have you heaped burning mountains of woe upon me. Proceed, executioner, torment me on, since you have once begun.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: This is not more a cause of anguish to yourself, than it has proved to me this day.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Tell me, who bought her?

sp.speaker: BUT.
sp.p: I' faith, I do not know.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Well, is this a good friend giving one his aid?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: The same that you see me doing, die with grief. But did you make enquiry, what was the appearance of the person that had bought her? Perhaps the damsel might have been traced out by that means.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Ah! wretch that I am----

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Do cease lamenting; attend to that which you are now about.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: What have I done?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Proved the destruction of myself, and with myself of your own word.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: The Gods know that that is not any fault of mine.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: A fine thing, indeed! You mention the Gods, who are absent, as witnesses; how am I to believe you in that?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Why, it rests with your own self what to believe; with myself, what to say, that rests with me.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: On that point you are ready, so as to give answer like for like; but as to what you are requested, you are lame, blind, dumb, defective, and weak. You promised that you would trick my father; I myself supposed that I was entrusting the matter to a skilful person, and I entrusted it to an utter stone.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: What could I do?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What could you do, do you ask me? You should have enquired, and asked who he was or whence he was, of what lineage; whether he was a citizen or a foreigner----

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: They said that he was a citizen of Attica.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: At least, you should have found out where he lives, if you couldn't the name.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: No person was able to say he knew.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: But at least you should have enquired what was the appearance of the man.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: I did do so.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Of what figure, then, did they say he was?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: I'll tell you: grey-headed, bandy-legged, pot-bellied, wide-mouthed, of stunted figure, with darkish eyes, lank jaws, splay-footed rather.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You are mentioning to me not a human being, but a whole storehouse, I don't know what, of deformities. Is there anything else that you can tell about him?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: It is just as much as I know.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I' troth, for sure, with his lank jaws he has caused my jaw to dropHe has caused my jaw to drop: Literally, "he has given me a great evil." He puns upon the resemblance of the words "malum," an "evil," and "mala," the "jaw.". I cannot endure it; I'm determined that I'll go hence in exile. But what state in especial to repair to, I'm in doubt; Megara, Eretria, Corinth, Chalcis, Crete, Cyprus, Sicyon, Cnidos, Zacynthus, Lesbos, or Bœotia.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Why are you adopting that design?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Why, because love is tormenting me.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: What say you as to this? Suppose, if when you have arrived there, whither you are now intending to go, you begin there to fall desperately in love, and there, too, you fail of success, then you'll be taking flight from there as well, and after that, again, from another place, if the same shall happen, what bounds, pray, will be set to your exile, what limits to your flight? What country or home can possibly be certain for you? Tell me that. Say now, if you leave this city, do you fancy that you'll leave your love here behind? If it is so fully taken as certain in your mind that so it will be, if you hold that as a point resolved upon, how much better is it for you to go away somewhere in the country, to be there, to live there, until the time when desire for her and passion have set you at liberty?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Have you now said your say?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: I have said it.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You have said it to no purpose; this is my full determination. I'll be off home, to pay my duty to my father and my mother; after that, unknown to my father, I'll fly from this country, or adopt some other plan. Goes into DEMIPHO'S house, leaving EUTYCHUS alone

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: to himself. How suddenly he has taken himself off and gone away. Ah! wretch that I am! if he goes away, all will say that it has happened through my remissness. I'm determined at once to order as many criers as possible to be hired to search for her to find her; after that, I'll go to the Prætor forthwith, and beg him to give me search-warrant officers in all the quarters of the city; for I find that nothing else whatever is now left for me to do. (Exit.)

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: to herself. Since a messenger came to me in the country from my husband, that he couldn't come into the country, I made up my mind, and came back to follow after him who fled from me. But looking round I don't see our old woman Syra following. Aye, look, there she comes at last. with a bundle of green sprigs.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Why don't you go quicker?

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: By my troth, I cannot; so great is this burden that I'm carrying.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: What burden?

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: Fourscore years and four, and to that are added servitude, sweat, and thirst; these things as well which I am carrying weigh me down.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Give me something, Syra, with which to decorate this altar of our neighbourAltar of our neighbour: She alludes to Apollo Prostatorus: an altar or statue to whom was placed near the doors of most of the houses Athens; see the Notes to the Bacchides..

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: holding out a sprig. Present this sprig of laurel, then. DOR. Now do you go into the house.

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: I'm going. Goes into the house of LYSIMACHUS.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: laying the sprig on the altar. Apollo, I pray thee that thou wilt propitiously grant peace, safety, and health, unto our household, and that in thy propitiousness thou wilt show favour to my son. rushes out of the house, clapping her hands.

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: I'm utterly undone! Wretch that I am, I'm ruined! Ah! wretched me!

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Prithee, are you quite in your senses? What are you howling for?

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: Dorippa, my dear Dorippa!

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Prithee, why are you crying out?

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: Some woman, I know not who, is here in-doors in the house.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: What? A woman?

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: A harlot woman.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Is it so, really?

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: In serious truth. You know how to act very prudently, in not remaining in the country. A fool even could have found it out that she was the mistress of your very pretty husband.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: By heavens, I believe it.

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: taking her arm. Step this way with me, that you, my Juno, may see as well your rival Alcmena.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: I' troth, I certainly shall go there, as fast as I can. They go into the house of LYSIMACHUS.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: to himself. Is this too little of a misfortune that Demipho's in love, that he must be extravagant as well? If he had been inviting ten men of highest rank to dinner, he has provided too much. But the cooks he directed in such a way just as at sea the time-keeperThe time-keeper: The time was given to the rowers by the "pausarius," who is here called "hortator." The directions he gave were called 'celeusma," from the Greek keleu/w, "to order." Lysimachus probably means that Demipho has hired whole ranks of them is wont to direct the rowers. I hired a Cook myself, but I'm surprised that he hasn't come as I directed him. But who's this, I wonder, that's coming out of my house? The door's opening. He stands aside.

div2.stage: Enter DORIPPA, from the house of LYSIMACHUS.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: weeping. No woman ever will be, or ever has been, more wretched than myself in being married to such a husband. Alas! unhappy that I am! Just see, to what a husband have you committed yourself and the property you have! Just see, to what a person I brought ten talents for a portion; that I should see these things, that I should endure these insults.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: behind. I' troth, I'm undone; my wife's returned from the country already. I do believe she has seen the damsel in the house. But what she says I cannot distinctly hear from hence; I'll go nearer to her. Approaches her.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Ah! woe to wretched me!

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: behind. Aye, and to me as well.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: I'm utterly undone!

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: behind. As for me, i' faith, to my sorrow I'm downright undone! she has seen her. May all the Gods confound you, Demipho!

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: I' troth, this was it, why my husband wouldn't go into the country.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: behind. What shall I do now, but go up and speak to her? Goes up to her. The husband bids health to his wife. Are the country peopleAre the country people: There has been much discussion as to the meaning of this passage; it seems, however, pretty clear that it is only an indirect way of asking Dorippa why she has so suddenly left the country for town. Colman thinks, with some of the older Commentators, that Dorippa pouts, and makes no return to her husband's salutation, on which he observes that the town gentry are grown as unmannerly as the country bumpkins. The context will admit of this explanation, but it seems rather far-fetched. becoming townsfolk?

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: They are acting more decently than those who are not become country people.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Are the people in the country at all in fault?

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: I' faith, less so than the townsfolk, and much less mischief do they meet with for themselves.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: But in what have the townsfolk done wrong? Tell me that.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Whose woman is that in the house?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: What, have you seen her?

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: I have seen her.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Whose is she, do you ask?

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: I shall find out, in spite of you; i' faith, I long to know. But you are trying me on purpose.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Do you wish me to tell you whose she is? She, she---- Aside. Ah me! upon my faith, I don't know what to say.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Do you hesitate?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: aside. I never saw one who did it more.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: But why don't you tell me?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Nay, but if I may----

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: You ought to tell me.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: I cannot, you hurry me so; you press me as though were guilty.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: ironically. I know you are free from all guilt.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Speak out as boldly as you please.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Tell me, then.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: I, tell you?

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Why, it must be told, in spite of everything.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: She is---- Do you wish me tell her name as well?

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: You are trifling. I've caught you in the fact; you are guilty.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Guilty of what? If now I had no occasion for silence, now I shouldn't tell youI shouldn't tell you: This he says, in his confusion, by mistake for "I should tell you.". Why, this same woman is --

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Who is she?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: She----

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Marry, come up! don't you know who she is?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Why, yes, I do know. I've been chosen as an arbitrator with respect to her.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: An arbitrator? Now I know; you have invited her here to consult with you.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Why no; she has been given me as a deposit.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: ironically. I understand.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: By my troth, it's not anything of that sort.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: You are clearing yourself too soonClearing yourself too soon: "Numero." Rost thinks that this means "you have quite," or "satisfactorily cleared yourself;" Dorippa, of course, saying so in an ironical manner. She seems, however, rather to allude to his defending himself before he is accused. Lysimachus pretends that some persons have disputed the possession of Pasicompsa, and that she has been left in his hands by mutual consent, till he has given his decision..

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: aside. Too much of a business have I met with; really I'm stuck fast.

div2.stage: Enter a COOK, at a distance, with SCULLIONS and provisions.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: Make haste, get quickly on, for I've got to cook a dinner for an old gentleman in love. And, in fact, when I think of it again, it's to be cooked for ourselves, not him for whom we've been hired: for a person that's in love, if he has that with which he is in love, he esteems that as food, to see her, embrace her, kiss her, chat with her; but we, I trust, shall return well laden home. Step this way. But see, here's the old gentleman that hired us.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: aside. Why, look! I'm undone! here's the Cook.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: going up to LYSIMACHUS. We are come.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Be off!

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: How, be off?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: in a low voice. Hush! Be off!

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: What, I, be off?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Be off, I say.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: Are you not going to have a dinner?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: We are full already.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: But----

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: aside. I'm utterly undone.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: What say you? Have those persons ordered these things to be brought to you as well, between whom you were appointed arbitrator?

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: Is this person pointing to DORIPPA your mistress, whom a little time since you told me you were in love with, when you were buying the provisions?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Won't you hold your tongue?

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: A very pretty figure of a woman.! I' faith, she does love a sweetheart.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Won't you be off to perdition?

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: She's not amiss.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: But you are amiss.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: I' troth, I do fancy she's a nice bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Won't you be off? I'm not the person that hired you just now.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: How's that? Nay but, upon my faith, you are that very man.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: aside. Alas wretch that I am!

sp.speaker: A COOK.
