sp.p: Your wife's in the country, I suppose, whom you were saying a little time ago you hated full as much as vipers.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: I, said that to you?

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: Aye, to me, upon my faith.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: So may Jupiter love me, wife, I never did say that.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Do you deny that as well?

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: to DORIPPA. He didn't say he hated you, but his wife.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: This is made clear, that you detest me.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: But I deny it.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: And he said that his wife was in the country.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: pointing to DORIPPA. This is she. Why are you annoying me?

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: Because you say that you don't know me. Are you afraid of her?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: I'm wise in being so; for she's my only companion.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: Do you wish to use my services?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: I don't wish.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: Give me my pay.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Ask for it to-morrow; it shall be given you; for the present, be off. Aside. Alas, wretch that I am! I now find that that old saying is a true one, that some bad comes through a bad neighbour.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: to the SCULLIONS. Why are we standing here?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Why don't you be gone?

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: aside to LYSIMACHUS. If any inconvenience happens to you, that's not my fault.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: aside to the COOK. Why, you are utterly ruining wretched me

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: aside to LYSIMACHUS. I understand now what you want. You mean, you wish me to go away from here.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: aside to the COOK. I do wish it, I say.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: aside to LYSIMACHUS. I'll be off. Pay me a drachma.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: aside to the COOK. It shall be paid.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: aside to LYSIMACHUS. Then order it to be paid me, please. It can be paid in the meantime, while they are putting down the provisions.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: aside to the COOK. Why don't you be off? Can't you cease being troublesome? Slips the money into his hand.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: to the SCULLIONS. Come, do you set down those provisions before the feet of that old gentleman. These baskets I'll order to be fetched from your house either by-and-by or else to-morrow. To the SCULLIONS. Do you follow me. Exeunt, having set down the provisions.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Perhaps you are surprised at that Cook, that he came and brought these things. I'll tell you why it is.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: I'm not surprised if you do anything wrongful or criminal; and, by heavens, I'll not put up with it, that I am married thus unfortunately, and that harlots are brought into my house in this way. Syra, go ask my father, in my name, to come here directly together with you.

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: I'll go.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Prithee, wife, you don't know what the matter is. In set form now will I make oath, that I have never had anything to do with her. Exit SYRA. What, is Syra gone now? By heaven, I'm undone! DORIPPA goes into the house.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: to himself. But, see, she's off as well! Woe to wretched me! Then, neighbour Demipho, may the Gods and Goddesses confound you, together with your mistress and your intriguings! He has most unjustly loaded me with suspicions; he has stirred up enemies against me. At home my wife is most infuriated. I'll be off to the Forum, and tell this to Demipho, that I'll drag this woman by the hair into the street, unless he takes her hence out of this house wherever he chooses. Goes to the door and calls. Hark you! wife, wife! although you're angry at me, you'll order, if you are wise, these things to be carried hence indoors. We shall be able by-and-by to dine all the better upon the same.

div2.stage: Enter SYRA and EUTYCHUS, at a distance, on opposite sides.

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: to herself. Whither my mistress sent me, to her father ----, he's not at home; they said that he has gone off into the country. Now, I'll take home this answer. I' faith, the women do live upon hard terms, and, wretched creatures, on much more unjust ones than the men. For if a husband has been keeping a mistress without the knowledge of his wife, if the wife comes to know it, the husband gets off with impunity; if, unknown to the husband, the wife goes from the house out of doors, a pretext arises for the husband, the marriage is dissolvedThe marriage is dissolved: She alludes to the facility with which at Rome, where the Play was performed, wives were divorced on the merest suspicion of infidelity.. I wish the law was the same for the husband as for the wife; for the wife that is a good one, is content with one husband; why, any the less, should the husband be content with one wife? By my troth, I'd give cause, if men were punished in the same way (if any one should be keeping a mistress unknown to his wife), as those women are repudiated who are guilty of a slip, that there should be more divorced men than there are women now.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: to himself, apart. I'm quite tired with hunting the whole city through; I find nothing whatever about this woman. But my mother has returned from the country; for I see Syra standing before the house. Syra!

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: Who is it that's calling me?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: 'Tis I, your master and foster-child.

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: turning round. Save you, my foster-child. EUT. Has my mother returned from the country then? Answer me.

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: Aye, for her own especial sake and that of the family.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: What is it that's the matter?

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: That very pretty father of yours has brought a mistress into the house.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: How say you?

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: Your mother, on arriving from the country, found her at home.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: By my troth, I didn't think my father was a person for those practices. Is the woman now even still in-doors?

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: Even still.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Do you follow me. He goes into the house of LYSIMACHUS.

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: to herself. How nowHow now?: From the commencement of this line to the end of the act is generally considered to be spurious; probably it is the work of some zealous critic of the middle ages, who fondly thought to improve the Play as it stood. He introduces Peristrata as complaining of the conduct of her husband, in depriving her son of his mistress, but never suspecting what is the true state of the case; an opportunity for a Comic dilemma, which Plautus himself, had he intended to introduce the character, would probably not have neglected.? Do I see Peristrata here, the wife of Demipho? She quickens her pace; she glances about with her eyes; she turns herself round; she inclines her neck on one side. I'll observe from here what matter she's about; it's something of importance, whatever scent she's upon. Stands aside.

div2.stage: Enter PERISTRATA and LYCISSA, from the house of DEMIPHO.

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: The Goddess AstarteThe Goddess Astarte: Astarte. The author seems to allude to Venus under this name. Cicero tells us that Astarte was the Syrian Venus. This soliloquy of Peristrata is very obscure and confused, and couched in most crabbed language, but her intention seems to be to descant upon the supreme sway of love. is the might of mortals and of the Gods, their life, their health; she, the same, who is likewise their death, destruction, downfall, the seas, the earth, the heaven, and the stars. Whatever Temples of Jove we inhabit, they are guided by her nod; her do they obey; to her do they pay regard; what displeases her, the other Deities do quickly put aside. Whatever pleases her, that, all things, which live and have sense, do pursue. Some she tortures, destroys; others, with her own milk does she nourish and raise aloft; but those whom she tortures, they live and enjoy their senses; those whom she hastens to rear and raise aloft, these last indeed do perish forthwith, and to their sorrow use their senses. Then, well-wishers, they lie prostrate, objects of dislike they bite the ground, grovel upon their faces, roar out, and make a riot; and when they think they live, then in especial do they rush on to ruin, then, then do they show eagerness in the pursuit of the object beloved; young men stumble, aged men likewise are led away. They love themselves; the object which they love, they wish to be loved and known. But if at that age they begin to fall in love, much more grievous is their madness. But if they do not love, then they hate, they are morose, too, and wayward; tattlers, haters, ill-disposed, passionate, envious for themselves and theirs. What they have formerly been shamelessly guilty of themselves, if it is done in a more quiet way, fathers do not tolerate as they ought to do; but they proclaim it, and indecently cry it out aloud.

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: apart. So far as I understand, Demipho is treating this lady badly too.

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: This is the truth. My son is in love and is dying; when his father came to know of it, he was enraged beyond bounds. What insanity is this? This same husband of mine at one time packed my son off to Rhodes to traffic; now, according to the news Acanthio brings, he'll be betaking himself into banishment. O unjust father! O unfortunate son! whither will you betake yourself? Where will you leave your mother? Shall I pass my life bereft? Shall I lose my son? I will not endure it. Has his father sold her? Wherever she shall be found, the mother will redeem her. Do you tell me, Lycissa, do they suppose that she was brought into this neighbourhood?

sp.speaker: LYCISSA
sp.p: pointing to the house of LYSIMACHUS. To that, I fancy; to the house of a certain old gentleman, a friend.

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: Here, there is no one that 1 know of besides Lysimachus.

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: apart. They are mentioning Lysimachus. It's a wonder if the old fellows, who are neighbours, haven't been going halves in the same nest.

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: I'll go look for Dorippa, his wife. The door of the house of LYSIMACHUS opens.

sp.speaker: LYCISSA
sp.p: Why go look for her? Don't you see her?

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: Indeed, I do see her. Let's listen; she's muttering something in a passion, I know not what, to herself. They stand aside.

div2.stage: Enter DORIPPA, from the house of LYSIMACHUS.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: to herself. Syra hasn't come back, whom, poor wretch, it's now a long time since I sent to fetch my father; in her very slowness, she has either hardened into a stone, or she has stopped from swelling with the sting of a serpent.

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: apart. I'm undone; here's my mistress, she's looking after me.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: continuing. I cannot remain at home; my eyes cannot abide that pretty young harlot; I would have shut her out of doors, but my son Eutychus prevented me. Still, I shan't altogether believe the news he brings.

sp.speaker: LYCISSA
sp.p: apart. Do you hear, mistress?

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: apart. I hear; let her go on.

sp.speaker: LYCISSA
sp.p: apart. I'll let her. DOR. to herself. He says that she has come hither to our house for the sake of an old gentleman, a friend; that he has her for sale, so that he may withdraw her from his son, who's in love with her. This really is a falsehood, either in my husband or my son; the accounts differ. The husband says that she was given him as a deposit; but the son says that she's on sale.

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: apart. I'll go meet her on a sudden, that she mayn't find out that I've been loitering.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: In this matter I shan't believe my son, who's acting in compliance with his father; for, for him, like a regular cuckooA regular cuckoo: Plautus, on more than one occasion, calls an adulterer by this epithet., has he determined to tell abundance of lies: for my own part I shall believe the Cook, in preference. But see, here's Syra. How the old witch does run. Syra!

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: Who's calling me? Stares around her.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: The Gods send a plague upon you!

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: Mistress, if you are wise, bestow this upon your rival and your husband in preference.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: For saying that, I'm no longer angry with you. But where's your father? Why does he delay? Does gout hinder the man?

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: He's lame with neither gout nor chalk-stonesNor chalk- stones: "Articularius" Literally, "having a disease in the ioints.", whom his feet carry into the country.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Not at home?

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Where then?

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: They say he's in the country, and that it's uncertain whether he'll return to-day, he has such a large account with his bailiff.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Everything is befalling me this day contrary to my wishes. I shan't live till the evening, unless I drive that hussy away from the house. She turns to the door. I'm going home.

sp.speaker: LYCISSA
sp.p: apart. The mistress is going away.

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: apart. What, going away? Call her.

sp.speaker: LYCISSA
sp.p: calling. Dorippa! Dorippa!

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: turning round. What nuisance is this? Who's calling me back?

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: I'm not a nuisance, but a well-wisher; and it's your friend Peristrata addresses you. Prithee, do stay.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Why, Peristrata--i' faith, I didn't know you: dreadful vexation is tormenting and agitating me.

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: This I enquire about--prithee don't deny me. I heard you just now; tell me what annoyance is troubling you.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Peristrata, so may the Gods prosper your only son, do kindly lend me your attention; none could be given me more agreably: our ages are alike; together we grew up; we have husbands alike in age; with no one do I converse with greater pleasure. I'm really annoyed with good reason. What now would your feelings be, if at this time of life your husband Demipho were to bring a mistress before your eyes?

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: Has he brought one?

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: So it is.

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: She's at your house?

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: At my house; aye, and cooks were hired; a banquet was being prepared, if my coming hadn't upset everything. Venus and Cupid are tormenting the wretched old fellow at an unseasonable time.

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: But these things are trifles, Dorippa. I wish that I wasn't more wretched.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Trifles?

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: Really trifles.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: What worse could your husband do?

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: Aye, worse than worse.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: What is it? Prithee do say. As you to me, so I to you, let's give advice to each other what needs to be done, It's an old saying, that, "he's truly wise who is wise at the risk of another."

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: Dorippa, I have an only son; do you know that?

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: I do know it.

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: Him his father some time ago packed off from his own house to Rhodes.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: For what reason?

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: Because he was in love.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: For that very thing?

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: Yes, and the very same thing now as well--inasmuch as he had brought a female slave here, his father coming to know of it, took her away, and put her up for sale.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Aye, aye, I know it; my son told me the truth. I fancied she was the mistress of my husband. To whom was she entrusted?

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: To a certain old gentleman in this neighbourhood, his friend. I think that he has no other friend here except your husband.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: aside. It certainly is she. To PERISTRATA. What does your son?

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: He declares that he'll leave this city.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: The matter's in a safe position. What if he finds her?

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: I imagine he'll stay.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Beyond expectation we are saved; don't doubt it; she's at my house.

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: At your house? It was she, I suppose, about whom I heard you talking just now.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: It was she.

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: O well done; I love you with reason; you've restored me my son. Do let me see her.

sp.speaker: DORIPPA
sp.p: Let's go in-doors then.

sp.speaker: PERISTRATA
sp.p: Let's go. Turning round. Come here, Lycissa. Do you go tell these things to Acanthio. I'll go here to Dorippa's house. Exit LYCISSA. DORIPPA, PERISTRATA, and SYRA go into the house of LYSIMACHUS.

div2.stage: Enter CHARINUS, from the house of DEMIPHO, in a travelling habit.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: looking towards the door. O higher and lowerHigher and lower: According to some writers, the threshold was sacred to Vesta Tertullian mentions a Deity called "Limentinus," or "the God of the Threshold." portions of the threshold, now both of you farewell. This day for the last time do I raise this foot within my father's house. The ease, the enjoyment, the in-dwelling, the habitation of this house is henceforth for me cut off, destroyed, and alienated. I am undone! The household Gods of my parents, the Lar the father of the familyFather of the family: The "Lares" seem to have been divided into two classes--the private and the public Lares. The private, or "familiares," were probably the same as the "Penates," under another name. The public Lares were the "urbani," presiding over the cities; "rustici," over the country; "compitales," over cross-roads; "marini," over the sea., to you do I recommend, that you will kindly protect the possessions of my parents. I shall now seek other household Gods for myself, another Lar, another city, another state. The people of Attica I do detest; for where worse manners are on the increase every day, where, those who are friends, those who are faithless, you are not able, to distinguish, and where that is torn away from you, which especially pleases your taste, there, in fact, if a kingdom were given one, that country is not desirable. Stands aside in deep thought.

div2.stage: Enter EUTYCUHS, from the house of LYSIMACHUS, at a distance.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: to himself. Thou who art the overlooker of Gods and of men, and the mistress of mortals as well, inasmuch as thou hast indulged me in this hope that I entertained, I do return thee thanks. What Deity is there now that is joyous with gladness like mine? That was at home which I was in search of. There did I find six companions, life, friendship, my native land, festivity, mirth, and jollity. On finding these, at the same moment did I utterly destroy ten very bad things, wrath, hatred, folly, ruin, perverseness, grief, tears, exile, want, and loneliness. Ye Gods, I pray you grant me a speedy opportunity of meeting him.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: to himself, not seeing EUTYCHUS. I'm ready prepared, as you see. Pride I cast aside; I'm my own companion, attendant, horse, groom, esquire; I'm my own master, I, too, obey myself; for my own self do I carry what I require. O Cupid! how powerful art thou. For easily dost thou render any one resolute through thy deeds, and then again, the same person diffident forthwith from being over bold.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: to himself. I'm thinking which way to run in search of him.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: continuing. The matter's resolved upon, that I'll seek her everywhere, wherever in the world she has been carried off from hence; and neither shall any river stand in my way, nor mountain, nor the sea, indeed, nor heat, nor cold; I dread neither wind nor hail; the torrents of rain I'll submit to; labour, heat, and thirst, will I endure. I'll neither stop nor rest anywhere at night, or in the day, assuredly, before I shall have met with either my mistress or my death.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: looking round. Some voice, I know not who's, flew to my ear. CHAR. continuing. You do I invoke, ye Lares of the roadsLares of the roads: He seems here to allude to the class of Lares who were usually called "Compitales," and whose statues were erected at the cross-roads. Varro tells us that there were 265 stations for Lares at the corners of the streets of Rome., that you will kindly lend me aid.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: seeing CHARINUS. Jupiter! isn't that Charinus?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: turning round. Fellow-citizens, fare ye well.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: aloud. Charinus, stop, this instant.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Who calls me back?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Hope, Safety, Victory.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What do you want with me?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: To go along with you.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Look for another companion; these companions that have possession of me, will not part with me.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Who are they?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Care, misery, sickness, tears, and lamentation.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Drive away those companions, and look this way and return.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: If indeed you wish to speak to me, do you follow. Moves on.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Stop, this instant!

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You do amiss, in delaying me as I haste; the sun is setting.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: If you would make haste in this direction, just as you are hastening in that one, you'd be doing more rightly; this way there is now a prospering gale, only tack about. Here is a fair Westerly breeze; there is a showery Southern blast. The one causes a calm; the other stirs up all the waves. Betake yourself towards the land, Charinus, in this direction. Don't you see right opposite? Black clouds and showers are coming on. Look now to the left, how full the heaven is of brightness. Don't you see right opposite?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: He has thrown religious scruplesThrown religious scruples: He considers the remark made by Eutychus as ominous, which it would be impious for him to disregard. in my way; I'll betake myself in that direction. Turns towards EUTYCHUS.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: You are wise. O Charinus, turn your steps, and turn your feet as well, in the opposite direction, Extend your arm. Catch hold of me. Do you hold me new?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I'm holding you.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Hold on, then. Whither now were you going?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Into banishment.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: What to do there?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: As a wretched person would.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Don't fear; this instant shall I restore you to joyousness before you go away.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I'm going. Moves.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: A thing that you especially long to hear, the same shall you hear for you to rejoice at. Stay this instant; I'm come as a friend, full of the kindest feelings.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Your mistress----

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What of her?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: I know where she is.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Prithee, do you?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: She's safe and sound.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Where is she safe?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: I know where.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I'd much rather I did.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Can't you possibly be calm in your feelings?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What if my feelings are agitated?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: I'll bring them for you into a safe and tranquil state; don't you fear.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Prithee * * * do say where she is --where you've seen her. Why are you mute? Speak--you are torturing to death wretched me by your silence.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: She isn't far from here.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Why then don't you point her out, if you see her?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: I' faith, I don't see her at this moment; but I saw her just now.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Why, then, don't you cause me to see her?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: I will cause it.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: That means a long time for one in love.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Are you still in apprehension? I'll disclose it all. No person is there living more beloved by me than is he who has got her; nor is there one to whom it is right that I should be a better wisher.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I don't care about that; I'm looking for her.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: About her, then, I'm telling you. Really, this has not come into my mind but this moment, to tell it you----

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Tell me, then, where she is.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: In our house.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: If you are telling the truth, a worthy house, and aptly built, I deem it. But how am I to credit that? Have you seen her; or do you speak from hearsay?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: I've seen her myself.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Who took her to your house?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Why, you're asking an unfair question. What matters it to you with whom she came?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: So long as she's there----

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: She certainly is.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Then, for these tidings, do you wish whatever you please.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: What if I do wish?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Pray to the Gods to bring its fulfilment.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: You are laughing at me.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: My fortunes, in fine, are redeemed, if I can see her. But why don't I lay aside this garb? Goes to the door of DEMIPHO'S house, and calls. Hallo, somebody, come here this instant out of doors. Come out, and bring me thence a cloak this way.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Well, now how much you do gratify me.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: to a BOY who enters, bringing his cloak. You boy, who have come with such speed, take my scarf giving it, and now stand aside there; that, if these things are not true, I may hasten to go upon this intended journey. To EUTYCHUS. Are you telling the truth?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Really, Charinus, you are not ashamed of anything. Don't you believe me?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: For my part, I really do believe everything that you tell me. But why don't you introduce me to her, that I may see her?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Wait a little.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Why am I to wait?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: It's not a convenient moment to go into the house.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You are torturing me to death.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: There's no need, I tell you, for you to go into the house just now.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Answer me-for what reason?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: She's not at leisure.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Because it isn't convenient to her.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Is it so? Not convenient to her who loves me, and whom I love in return? He's trifling with me in every way. I'm too foolish to believe him. He's only delaying me. Turns to the BOY. I'll put on my scarf again.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Stop a little, and listen to this.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: taking off the cloak. You boy, take this cloakTake this cloak: Though commonly rendered "cloak," the pallium" differed materially from that article of dress. It was a square piece of cloth, which came direct from the loom in that shape, and required no cutting out by the tailor. The "pallia" were mostly worn in an undyed state, consequently white, brown, and grey were the prevailing colours. They were sometimes dyed of crimson, purple, and saffron colour. Sometimes they were striped, like our plaids or checks. Flowers were sometimes interwoven, and occasionally with gold thread. Wool was the most common material. They were not only used for wearing, but for spreading over beds and couches, and covering the body during sleep. Sometimes they were used as carpets, and sometimes as awnings or curtains; and indeed the word as often means "a blanket" as a garment. When worn, the "pallium" was passed over the left shoulder, then drawn behind the back and under the right arm, leaving it bare, and then thrown again over the left shoulder See Dr. Smith's Dictionary of Greek and Roman Antiquities., please. Puts on the travelling scarf.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Really this hasn't come but this moment into my mind to tell it you. My mother's dreadfully angry with my father, because he has brought into the house a harlot before her very eyes, while she was away in the country. She suspects that she's his own mistress.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: not attending to him. I've taken up my beltMy belt: The "zona," "girdle" or "belt," would be employed by the traveller to tuck up his long clothing, for the sake of expedition; it was also used either as a purse or for the purpose of holding the purse. The traveller would require his sword for the purposes of safety, while the "ampulla," or "leather bottle," was to hold the oil with which the feet were anointed when galled with walking.. Puts it on.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: She's now enquiring into this matter in-doors.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: inattentive. Now my sword's in hand. Taking it from the BOY.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: But if I were now to introduce you?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: inattentive. I'll take my bottle, and be off from here. Moves.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Stop, stop, Charinus!

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You are mistaken; you can't deceive me.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: And, i' faith, I have no wish.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Why, then, don't you allow me to proceed upon my journey?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: I won't let you.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I'm delaying myself. Boy, do you this instant be off hence in-doors. The BOY goes into the house. Now I've ascended the chariot; now I've taken the reins in my hands. Imitating the action of a charioteer.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: You are not in your senses.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Feet of mine, why don't ye betake yourselves into the chariot, straight for Cyprus, since my father determines on my banishment?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: You are silly. Prithee, don't be saying this.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: as though to himself. I'm resolved to persist--to use my endeavours to seek her out where she is.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Why, she's at our house.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: as though to himself. For what that person said, he told a falsehood in it.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Really, I told you the truth.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: continuing. Now I've come to Cyprus.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Nay, but follow me, that you may see her whom you are looking for. Moves towards his FATHER'S house.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: pretending not to hear. Enquiring there, I didn't find her. EUT. I'll not care then for my mother's anger.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: still pretending. I'll still go on to seek her. Now I've got to Chalcis; I see there my former host at Zacynthus; I tell him why I've come thither; I make enquiry if he has heard say who has brought her thither, who has got possession of her.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Why don't you cease that nonsense, and step with me this way in-doors?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: still pretending. My host answered that figs grew, not bad ones, at Zacynthus.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: He didn't say false there.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: continuing. But he says that he has heard about my mistress, that she's here at Athens.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Really, this Zacynthian is quite a CalchasCalchas: The soothsayer who attended the Grecian army to Troy..

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: continuing. I get aboard ship, and start at once. I'm now at home; now I've returned from banishment. My friend, Eutychus turning towards him, greetings to you! How have you been? How are my parents? Are they well? Do you come to my mother, you say--you invite me kindly; you speak politely. At your house to-morrow; for the present at home. So it is proper; so it ought to be done.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: How now? What are you dreaming about? This man's not in his senses.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Why don't you, as a friend, make haste to cure me then?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Follow me, please.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: running close behind him. I'm following.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: turning round. Softly, pray; you are treading on my heels. Don't you hear me?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I've heard you for some time past.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: I want a reconciliation to be made between my father and mother; for now she's in a passion----

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: pushing him. Only do go on. EUT. About that woman----

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: pushing him. Only do go on.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Therefore take care----

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: pushing him. Nay, but do go on then; I'll make her as mild as Juno is when she's kind to Jupiter. They go into the house of LYSIMACHUS.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: [DemiphoThis, and the next ten lines, are generally looked upon as spurious. They have probably been inserted by some busy interpolater, to supply what Plautus had intended us to suppose as having transpired between Demipho and Lysimachus before they enter., this saying of the wise, I think you have often heard, "Pleasure is the bait for misfortune;" because, by it, not less are men aught than are fishes with the hook Although aged people fly from it, still you don't pay that regard to your old age: since it hasn't even withdrawn love from you, but has forced you to it even more vehemently. Wherefore it utterly confounds yourself and your understanding and your mind, and dazzles your eyesight. Myself too have you brought into great trouble, and I know not what to do,

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Lysimachus, this is the will of the Gods, not of men. If you reflect upon this with yourself, you will be of opinion that you are not doing right, in censuring so heavily a person your friend and the sharer of your secrets.] As though you yourself had never done anything like this action.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: By heavens, never. I took care not to do anything: wretch that I am, I am scarcely alive; for my wife is lying all in a ferment about her.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: But I'll undertake to clear you, so that she mayn't be angry.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Follow me--but I see my son coming out.

div2.stage: Enter EYTUCHUS, from the house of LYSIMACHUS.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: as he comes out, to CHARINUS, within. I'll go to my father, that he may know my mother's wrath is appeased. I'll return just now.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: to DEMIPHO. The beginning pleases me. Going up to EUTYCHUS. What are you about? How goes it, Eutychus?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Extremely opportunely have you both met me.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Your wife is peaceful and appeased. Give me your right hands this moment. Shakes hands with them both.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: The Gods are favouring me.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: to DEMIPHO. I bring you word that you have got no mistress.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: The Gods confound you. Why, prithee, what affair is this?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: I'll tell you. Give your attention then, both of you.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Well then, we are giving you our attention, both of us.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Those who are born of a good family, if they are of bad tendencies, by their own faultiness withdraw nobleness from their rank, and disgrace their disposition.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: He says what's true.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Then it's to yourself he says it.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: For this reason is this the more true; for at this time of life, it wasn't just for you to take away from your son, a young man, his mistress, purchased with his own money.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: How say you? Is she the mistress of Charinus?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: aside. How the rogue does dissemble.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Why, he said that he had bought her as a maidservant for his mother.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Was it for that reason, then, you bought her, you young lover, you old boy?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Very well said, i' troth! Proceed, proceed. I'll stand by him here on the other side. Let's both load him well with such speeches as he's worthy of.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: aside. I'm done for. EUT. Who has done an injustice so great to his blameless son; whom, in fact, upon my faith, I brought back home just when he was setting out in self-banishment; for he was going into exile.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Has he gone then?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: What, do you speak, you hobgoblin? At this time of life you ought to abstain from those pursuits.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: I confess it; undoubtedly I've acted wrong.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: What, do you speak, you hobgoblin? You ought at this time of life to have done with these guilty practices. Just as the seasons of the year, so different lines of conduct befit different ages; but if this is proper, that old fellows should be wenching in their old age, where in the world is our common welfare?

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Alas! wretch that I am! I'm undone.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: The young men are more in the habit of giving their attention to following those pursuits.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Troth, now, prithee, do take her to yourselves, with pigs and with basketWith pigs and with basket: "Cum porcis, cum piscinâ." This was probably a countrified expression, analogous to our phrases "with bag and baggage," "stump and rump.".

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Restore her to your son; let him have her, now, as he wishes.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: So far as I'm concerned, he may have her.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: High time, i' faith, since you haven't the power of doing otherwise.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: For this injury let him take what satisfaction he likes; only do you make peace, I beg of you, that he mayn't be angry with me. I' faith, if I had known it, or if, indeed, he had told me in the slightest way of joke that he was in love with her, I should never have proceeded to take her away from him so in love. Enitychus, you are his companion, preserve and rescue me, I beg of you. Make this old fellow your client. You shall say that I'm mindful of a kindness.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Entreat him that he'll pardon his offences and his youthful ageAnd his youthful age: Of course this is said in a tone of keen and well-merited satire..

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Heyday now, are you still persisting in inveighing against me with your airs? I trust that a like opportunity will befall me as well for returning you a similar compliment.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: I've long made an end of those pursuits.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: And really so shall I from this time forward.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Not a bit of it. Through usage your inclinations will be leading you to it again.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Prithee, do now be satisfied. Rather, scourge me with thongs even, if you like.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: You say right. But that your wife will do, when she comes to know of this.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: There's no need for her to come to know of it.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: What's that? She shan't come to know of it; don't be afraid. Let's go in-doors; this place isn't a suitable one for your practices, for there to be persons to overhear who are passing through the street, while we are talking.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Why, faith, you say what's right; that way the story will be shorter. Let's be off

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Your son is in-doors here at our house.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: It's very good. We'll pass that way through the gardenThrough the garden: He means that he will be able to go home the back way, so that perhaps his wife may not see whence lie has come. This line shows that the houses of Lysimachus and Demipho are on the same side of the street, and not, as Cotter says, one on one side, the other on the other, with their doors opposite.--It may be here remarked, that it is not improbable that a considerable portion of this Play has perished. home.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Eutychus, I want this affair to be settled before I set my foot again within doors.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Each person thinks about his own concerns. Answer me this: do you know for certain that your mother isn't angry with me?

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: I do know it.

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Take care.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Trust me for it. Are you satisfied?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: I am. But still, troth now, prithee, do take care.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Don't you believe me?

sp.speaker: LYSIMACHUS
sp.p: Yes, I do believe you; but still I'm dreadfully afraid.

sp.speaker: DEMIPHO
sp.p: Let's go in-doors.

sp.speaker: EUTYCHUS
sp.p: Aye, but I think we must pronounce. the law for the old men before we depart, on what terms they are to keep check upon themselves and to be continent. Whoever shall be sixty years of age, if we know of any one, whether husband or, i' faith, whether bachelor, in fact, who goes a wenching, upon these terms shall we deal with him; we shall deem him a fool. And, i' faith, so far as we're concerned, he shall be in want who has squandered away his property. And let no one hereafter forbid his youthful son to be in love and to keep a mistress, so it be done in a decent manner. If he shall forbid him, let him, unknown to himself, suffer more loss than if he had openly permitted him. Let this law, then, from this night forward, be binding upon the old men. To the AUDIENCE. Young men, kindly fare you well; and if this law, enacted for the sake of the old ones, pleases you, it is right that you should give us loud applause.
